4.body:
[Snow Real Magic](https://www.curseforge.com/minecraft/mc-mods/snow-real-magic/files/all?filter-game-version=1738749986%3A628) makes tall grass and snow coexist in the same block, making snowy biomes look less jarring. I used to use it with [Serene Seasons](https://www.curseforge.com/minecraft/mc-mods/serene-seasons) and [Serene Tweaks](https://www.curseforge.com/minecraft/mc-mods/serene-tweaks) to make winter look a lot nicer.

4.author: trashpanda0088
4.body:
Here's a screenshot album of what I currently use for weather: [https://imgur.com/a/avXE7va](https://imgur.com/a/avXE7va)

I use a resource pack called [Better Rain & Snow](https://www.planetminecraft.com/texture-pack/better-rain-amp-snow-texture-pack) which makes the default rain/snow more dense and visible, with some subtle fog. It's more noticeable when moving around. Should work on 1.12 since it's just a texture replacement. Or if I misunderstood and you want *less* visually obtrusive weather, there's a good pack called [Soft Weather](https://www.curseforge.com/minecraft/texture-packs/soft-weather) you could use.

My shader of choice is [Complementary Reimagined](https://www.curseforge.com/minecraft/customization/complementary-reimagined) which mostly adds fog and color change instead of making the particles themselves more noticeable. Not sure if a newer shader like this would work on 1.12, but you could give it a try.

I tried combining Better Rain & Snow and the shader, and there was a very slight difference. Particles seemed more noticeable if I looked hard enough, but I think the shader's effects and fog overpower most of it. That's about the best you're gonna get; there are mods that overhaul rain/snow into individual particles but none of them are for 1.12.

6.author: Darkhax
6.body:
I just tried setting this up and it worked fine. I am guessing you have something misconfigured. Here are the steps I took.

1. Download GraalVM Community Edition 22.3.1 from [the GitHub](https://github.com/graalvm/graalvm-ce-builds/releases/tag/vm-22.3.1).
2. Extract the zip to a reasonable place such as `C:\Program Files\Java\graalvm-ce-java17-22.3.1`
3. In Prism open settings and set the Java installation path to the javaw.exe in your graal folder. For example `C:/Program Files/Java/graalvm-ce-java17-22.3.1/bin/javaw.exe`.
4. The game should run with no further changes.

Note that while GraalVM has a good reputation for being high performance, these benefits have not been demonstrated for modded Minecraft environments. It's still worth checking out if you're curious but there may be compatibility issues with certain mods and modloader features.

10.author: Seraphaestus
10.body:
This is fantastic! Had this kind of Infinifactory-like idea in my head for a while, glad someone is making it! Love the thought process too, plus the editing on the video

The only thing I would criticize is the story, which sounds a little too forced(?) to me. Theming is super important imo for making the player feel immersed and like they're doing something diegetically meaningful.

For example, instead of using bedrock, you can make certain regular blocks indestructable and build the room out of those, to decorate it. One theme I'd considered for this kind of idea is that you're one of Santa's elves, constructing different types of presents. The room in this case could be a room of Santa's workshop. You could even have a fake door that can't be opened (so the room is still enclosed), but gives the player the feel that it's a real space. 

In my original conception, it was something like Santa had crashed at your house, and the playable area was your living room, except you're resized with Pehkui so the blocks are tiny and the room is built at a larger scale, which justifies the scale of the things you're making with blocks. Plus you could use a Create train as a model train running on the carpet around the Christmas tree, which was a really cool visual in my head.

Or maybe you're a futuristic assembly-line construction robot that's gained sentience and has to eventually try to escape, while solving rooms, Portal-style. I think that one would be a lot of fun, actually.

10.author: TheRealQuentin765
10.body:
I wrote a massive thing then my phone died, so i'm gonna keep this short (heh 'short' did not happen)

I think that your consideration in the story is valid.

However the situation that is christmas themed, although quite jolly, is not a good solution as it alienates players who do not have that belief or any month that is not near christmas.

The current story checks the boxes exceedingly well, which are more important than I let on in the video.

This is because instead of just making machines that take a input and build a single output multiple times, it would be more interesting if it was inputs that change and outputs that need to react

This can be seen in the comparison of opus magnum and warp factory (a underrated game imo).

However these puzzles are significantly harder to solve in base in reality.

For example in warp factory about half of them are somewhat seem like real puzzles (maximize the length of time it takes to bring the fuel rod (a green rectangle) to the output) while the rest give up and are an abstract (if the input is flat then output 1 block and if the input is L shaped then output one more block then the previous time or something.)

So that is why it is even more important to maximize the flexibility of the story for puzzles.

Also the bug story although not completely immersive at first, I have come up with a story with plot developments and twists and turns and eventually a climax and a 'final boss'. So I think it could be interesting enough.

I also have some floating ideas of how I could
make it much deeper, however I don't think I can push the medium of minecraft modpack too for a story. Also these are ideas that I have not been able to work out into a story line.

Overall I am not too attached to the currently story line, and would love to here you suggestions!

10.author: Seraphaestus
10.body:
Christmas is really a secular tradition for most people, so I really don't think it would alienate anyone worth catering to.

That's interesting though, having puzzles be about adaptation rather than a fixed automation. Not entirely sure how it'll work but I'll look forward to seeing more videos on it!

Maybe instead of it being a bug, it could be a human, with the big people outside being monsters of some sort who deliberately farm and trap humans in these automation cubes to do their labor for them? Sort of like a *Promised Neverland* kind of vibe. That might make it more intuitively immersive since it'd be easier to put yourself in the shoes of a person?

And not to sound like a broken record but you could even make parts of the cell out of glass and use Pehkui to make a giant creature looking at you from outside, that's a pretty cool visual

Honestly I think a lot of the design ideas I have tend to revolve around wowing the player with some cool set piece or visual. I think my problem with the bug concept as-is is that it doesn't feel quite so epic? Or  "high concept" perhaps is the term, like having a concept that can be easily summarised and used as a hook

14.author: OmegaX____
14.body: There's tons of good spells to make, the spell book is legitimately a multitool. It can be used for silk touching or using fortune on blocks when mining and can break obsidian or ancient debris itself (diamond pickaxe), cutting down entire trees (diamond axe), fighting at range (bow), smelting items (furnace), crafting items (crafting table), opening ender chest storage (well ender chest) and flying(Elytra) as you mentioned before to name just a few. 25.author: Puresteel_28
25.body:
I think there is some misunderstanding on the terminology here.

I assume you are talking about:

> Enable “Force threaded chunk rendering” in Forge’s client config (if you’re using Forge).

Forge is a modloader. The other major modloader is Fabric. Almost every modpack is either a Forge or Fabric pack. Modloaders pretty much determine what mods can be added to a modpack and are essential to running modded minecraft.

The FTB App is a Minecraft launcher. It is used to download, manage and play various modpacks.

Most of the FTB modpacks are Forge (there is a recent one that is Fabric). Direwolf's 1.19 pack is a Forge pack. So using the FTB app does not exclude you from accessing the threading chunk rendering option.

To get to this option, go to the main menu or Esc menu in your modpack. Look for an option like **Configs** or **Mod Options**. Once in, either search for **"Forge"** or scroll to it and select it. Go into the configs. Then look for “Force threaded chunk rendering”, and make sure it is turned on. That's what that bullet point is talking about. It has nothing to do with the launcher.

-------------------------------

To add and subtract mods, go to a modpack, look for three dots somewhere (should be next to Play), then open the Mods Folder from there. From there just drop the .jar of a mod you want to add, or delete the .jar of a mod you don't want. Then that's pretty much it. Becareful when updating modpacks though, they may 'forget' your manual changes. Just check the Mods folder everytime you play your modpack.

29.author: garry4321
29.body:
Hmm, If you PM me your specs, Im more than happy to help you troubleshoot this issue to the best of my knowledge. I've been troubleshooting game issues for like 20 years now, so I know that frustration. 

It could very well be that your world has too many entities and its bogging down your CPU. minecraft only uses one core, so if you have too much going on, it could certainly cause you lag as your single core tries to process everything going on.

I would also suggest trying to go so far from where everything you built is that it doesnt load the chunks on your client to see if that stops the lag.

31.author: Pittol
31.body: Basically you would have to dive deep into what each mod does, then turn off all the unnecessary stuff via configs or datapacks and scripts. Some tools to get it done would be spark to see what is causing performance issues, crafttweaker to make zen scripts to turn off items and badmobs to blacklist problematic entities. It is a process of fail and error often, adapting over time as you learn more and more about each mod and pretty much takes hundreds of hours of time to do properly. Thats why I advise ready pack

36.author: GirlWithCollar
36.body:
In the player.dat, the Waystones NBT data saves as UUIDs for each stone.

The have upwards of 40 waystones saved, it would frankly be easier to copy the data than try to fugure out the coordinates for each stone.

Especially if this happens in the future, I don’t want to have to teleport people around the map. This is the third time data has corrupted with this modpack.

Player data does not save and reverts back to what is was after uploading the new data. Deleting data, adding data, it doesn’t matter.

This is specifically the Grounded Origins Add-on by mo-shark and it adds classes where the player height is modified to be shorter, wider, or higher than the original player model. The penguin class seems to be the only class I cannot climb stairs with.

37.author: UlyssesB

46.author: skyyhacylon
46.body: I moderate on a discord channel that hosts a dedicated machine from pebble. Runs great but can still have TPS issues on an individual modpack if people aren't being smart about minimizing tps (lots of ticking mobs are an issue in ANY pack so lots of villagers in each person's base will always cause problems or lots of passives like the penguins in The Twilight Forest, endgame with super heavy automation packs like SB3 can run slow). I highly recommend learning to use the mod "observable" to find what's taking up tick time on your world or server regardless of who you host through. Sometimes it's not the server per se but what the players have done.

46.author: skyyhacylon
46.body:
That's just disabling rendering on the client side to reduce client-side lag (ie low frame rate) and has nothing to do with the entity on the server side. It's still there and still ticking.

Yeah, pebble has been great but keep in mind we have an entire dedicated machine to ourselves, it's not just some vm partitioned out that other people are running off of, so I can't say what that plays like with them. FWIW, the machine we run on has a powerful cpu (can't remember exactly what it is off the top of my head) and 128gb of ram.

50.author: zspacekcc
50.body:
Any chance the impacted ones are either on a chunk border (the machine is in one chunk and the conduit head is in the first block of the next chunk), or that the multi block is split between two chunks?

World loading can cause issues with multiblocks if they're split between chunks sometimes. If you want to check F9 in most modpacks will bring up the chunk borders. Then if you see one of the impacted machines split, try moving it and see if that resolves the issue.

50.author: DarkTemplar_of_Chaos
50.body:
ok so, after some checking and testing, it would seem that chunk boundaries are kind of the issue.

my main smeltery is all contained in a single chunk (I still build 3x3 like a filthy casual), and none of the conduits disconnect upon world load.

my gigantic tinker tank full of steam is sliced in half by chunk boundary, but works perfectly fine. no disconnects.

cetane boosted diesel tinker tank is sliced into quarters by chunks (boy did I fuck that up), and every conduit except one disconnects. 

the real anomalies are my tiny tinker tanks for hydrogen / oxygen / nitrogen / milk, those are all contained in one chunk but half the conduits connected to each disconnect. 

I can't figure out why, but you're absolutely right about it being chunk boundaries. I think the problem has to do with whether the conduit line goes over the chunk boundary, and how often the connected tanks have block updates, which tinker tank drains don't do on their own iirc

I think I'm just gonna switch to Gregtech multiblock tanks for all of these. should have plenty of titanium to make a couple hundred

50.author: DarkTemplar_of_Chaos
50.body:
shit you might be on to something.

I'm not gonna lie, I forgot F9 was still a thing. I thought that feature died when NEI was replaced by JEI, along with F7 for lighting. I'll try that when I load in.

my space platform is a jumbled mess anyway, it needs to be rebuilt xD

50.author: zspacekcc
50.body:
So typically the controller is what defines the multiblock. For the cetane tank, is the one that works in the same chunk as the controller, but the others are not?

The hydrogen/O2 tanks I have no idea on. Normally if both the tank and the head of the conduit are in the same chunk everything plays nice. 

Do you have a chunkloader near your base? I wonder if the chunkloader is getting loaded first and the causing havoc on everything else as it loads the chunks around it.

50.author: DarkTemplar_of_Chaos
50.body:
chunks are loaded by ftb utils, but afaik the chunks still have to load sequentially based off where you spawn in at before chunk loading takes place.

for the cetane tank, the one that works is weirdly the one on the opposite corner chunk from the controller, and moving the controller to that chunk does nothing but delete all of my turbo diesel... oops. well backups are a thing at least.

I think that one might be working because that chunk is the farthest from my spawn point, and therefore is the last to load in. since it's last, it sees a working multiblock and works fine I guess?

either way, swapping the hydrogen / oxygen / nitrogen tanks to GT multiblock ones seemed to fix them, probably because each individual block is a ticking tile entity.

55.author: Ridanisaurus
55.body:
There is a fun way I usually test ore gen with.

Create a minecraft:air based strata and just give it any random texture, like stone for example, and set your ore features to generate between 64-256, with filler type set to the air strata. It will actually consider air as a valid block, and will spawn floating in mid air. It's how I was able to get a good screenshots of the Dike, Dense, and Sphere deposits.

Hope that helps. If you can't figure it out, let me know and I can provide you with JSONs for testing.

61.author: DvDmanDT
61.body: How much ram do you have in your system and how much are you allocating to the game? How is your system performance in general when this happens? When stuff starts to freeze 10+ seconds, up to minutes, I'm thinking swapping, as in you're running out of free RAM in your entire system.

61.author: Xpertthiefftw
61.body:
My system has 32 gb of ram, 8 gb of which is allotted to minecraft. I heard having too much or too little Ram could be a problem, so I tried to keep it a decent level.

Whenever these freezes happen, everything else seems to continue fine. Music or videos and discord all seem ok. The only thing that freezes is minecraft.

61.author: DvDmanDT
61.body: Sounds reasonable. I'd still check task manager (assuming Windows..?) next time it happens. If memory is above 80%, chances are swapping is involved. What Java version are you using? Any special args or anything?

61.author: Xpertthiefftw
61.body: I'm using the most recent version of Java (version 8, update 361), and im on Windows 11. With my very basic understanding of Java, I tend not to attempt to tamper with args unless someone says I should as I have almost zero idea how they work.

61.author: DvDmanDT
61.body:
Versions sound good and you should indeed not need any args. Again, I'd try to keep an eye on Task Manager and the Performance tab and see if anything interesting happens when you tab back into the game after some AFK time. Like if memory rises or drops significantly.

I've never used Windows 11 so could be something new. As I said, swapping is a prime suspect whenever we're talking delays of these magnitudes, but another potential suspect would be something like some power saving feature, or some feature to reduce fan noise or similar. Could be some driver thing and/or one of those apps that vendors love shipping with laptops and other preinstalled systems. Other than that, I'm out of ideas. Hopefully someone else have more ideas. :)

61.author: Xpertthiefftw
61.body: Thanks for your help anyway. I appreciate the assistance

65.author: pikachuguy
65.body: FTB Essentials and FTB Ranks (for Forge) have tools and permissions you can use for this. Essentials adds commands like /sethome and Ranks allows you attach permissions to use commands to a rank. So say you want Members to use /sethome, you can edits perms so that Members can use /sethome but not /give or something like that.

67.author: DianaSt75
67.body: Hmm.. The concept is present in all abrahamic religions, so it's not just christianity. Now this goes into unstable territory, given prior reactions to what I thought to be common knowledge, but I'd argue that Eden being a garden of paradise is indeed common knowledge. Anything beyond the first book of the old testament might be different, but especially this particular idea of a garden of peace has been pictured so many times in art and elsewhere that I do not see how even non-christians could get around not knowing there's a clear reference for large parts of the US and Europe they need to take into account.

67.author: Connect_Sky8294
67.body: Yes but thats three religions what about norse paganism (my religion) hellenism celtic paganism hinduism sikhism

67.author: DianaSt75
67.body:
That's not the point - the point is, this particular concept has been used widely enough in art and culture over the centuries that I think it should be known beyond the borders of christianity. 

Another example would be Mohammed, founder of Islam. I do not need to be muslim myself to acknowledge that name in various permutations is central to muslim beliefs, and as such I should expect strongly worded reactions if I use that name anywhere lightly. 

Or, to stay with religious concepts, use the term zen somewhere without taking into account what it usually describes. Or various gods and godesses from Hinduism. 

Paganism is a bit different since it's not acknowledged to be widespread nowadays, and as such I'd be hesitant to expect everyone to know major concepts of those. Though, given how central Greek and Roman history is to the development of western civilization, I would assume knowledge of the really major players in each respective pantheon.
